user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_dev_dma_map:
```c
static int metal_linux_dev_dma_map(struct metal_bus *bus,
			     struct metal_device *device,
			     uint32_t dir,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_in,
			     int nents_in,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);

	return ldev->ldrv->dev_dma_map(lbus, ldev, dir, sg_in,
				       nents_in, sg_out);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_dev_dma_map:
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
...
struct linux_bus {
	struct metal_bus	bus;
	const char		*bus_name;
	struct linux_driver	drivers[MAX_DRIVERS];
	struct sysfs_bus	*sbus;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of the <string.h> functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) in the provided code. The function metal_linux_dev_dma_map simply retrieves ldev and lbus and forwards the call to ldev->ldrv->dev_dma_map; it does not call any string handling functions itself. The struct definitions declare fixed-size char arrays (dev_name, dev_path, cls_path) but declarations alone are not uses of string.h functions and do not demonstrate any out-of-bounds accesses. Potential locations that would need inspection (not present in the provided snippets) include: the implementation of ldev->ldrv->dev_dma_map and any other functions that read from or write to dev_name/dev_path/cls_path or other buffers — those implementations may use string.h functions and should be checked. Based on the supplied code fragments, there are no direct violations to report.
